726101f-a.title: Queens: Astoria Park.
726101f-a.text:
Astoria Park:
Twenty-sixth Ave., (foreground, not shown) north side, between East River (left) and 2nd Street (right), showing in the background the Hellgate Lighthouse and the field house of the Astoria Athletic
Field. Fort Stevens formerly occupied this site.
1922.
Eugene L. Ambruster Collection.

726098f-a.title: Queens: Astoria Park.
726098f-a.text:
Astoria Park (Queens): the band shells at the southern end of the park, seen from 19th Street and Hoyt Avenue. The Triborough Bridge was later erected here, just to the right of the shell. View 2 was taken from the bridge looking west across Hell Gate toward Manhattan. View 3 shows the Astoria Park swimming pool, viewing inland from the bridge. On the left is the Hell Gate railroad bridge.
P. L. Sperr  View 1: March 14, 1931
NO REPRODUCTIONS  Views 2,3: July 25, 1936

726099f-c.title: Queens: Astoria Park.
726099f-c.text:
Astoria Park (2ueens): Scenes of the Park on the East River shore. Note, in view 1, a portion of the steel structure of the Triborough Bridge under construction. View 2 shows kids playing on a mound while the park is being improved. View 3 shows an ancient house, one nf the remaining few homes from the time when this area was a fashionable residential district, and gas tanks.
P. L. Sperr  View 1 Sept. 20, 1934
NO REPRODUDTIONS  View 2: November 9, 1935
View 3: July 10, 1937

726100f-b.title: Queens: Astoria Park.
726100f-b.text:
(1)
Astoria Park, showing a small cottage opposite 24th Road in the Park. The Mallison Silk Mills at the left,face Twenty-fourth Ave.
April 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
The same, from another angle showing also the Hell Gate Bridge in
the background.
March 144, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
